author: Oliver Pickup
title: Rugby fitness: going from one extreme to another
text: When it comes to international rugby , the famous adage “by failing to prepare, you are preparing to fail”, has rarely been more appropriate. Becoming world champions in any sport is a tremendous challenge. Under Sir Clive Woodward, England came up short in their bid in 1999. En route to winning the trophy in 2003, Woodward enlisted the Royal Marines to help prepare his players. Talk about being out of your comfort zone. The approach can backfire. Before the 2003 competition there was mutiny in the South Africa camp after the players were forced to climb naked into a foxhole and soaked with ice-cold water. Meanwhile, before the 2011 tournament, the Wales squad had cryotherapy in Poland in temperatures of minus 70C. This year the home nations have gone to even greater lengths to be better prepared, in the belief that marginal gains could be the difference between success and failure. Warren Gatland’s Wales have endured brutal camps in Switzerland and Qatar, and Scotland head coach Vern Cotter enlisted French commandos to lead his squad on a mountain hike in the Pyrenees. Hosts England spent a fortnight at altitude in Denver, Colorado, in what Tom Wood, the England flanker, called “the toughest training of my career”. Next they must scale the heights of expectation and lift the game’s biggest trophy again. Keep calm and keep going Panic-busting tips from life coach Mark Maitland, changewithquiddity.com Picture your goal • “If your heart is pounding, ahead of a big challenge, try bringing to mind an image of what you want out of the situation, such as clutching your finisher’s medal. This will motivate you and spur you on” Reframe the situation • “When the going gets tough–say, at mile 20 of a marathon – try to distance yourself from the situation, as if you were a stranger. This will ease the pressure.” Break it down • “Focus on the process of the challenge. Breaking it down into smaller tasks or chunks will make it seem far less daunting.” • For more information on health and lifestyle, visit vitality.com
